Olive Leaf Bistro 'a gem' in Jeffersonville

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 12:03 p.m. EST November 5, 2014
Buy Photo

The souffl either raspberry or chocolate is a specialty of chef Jimmy Shraby, who runs the Olive Leaf Bistro in Jeffersonville. There also are plenty of Big Four Bridge views from the dining room. (Photo: By Matt Stone/The C-J )Buy Photo

Story Highlights

  • OLIVE LEAF BISTRO 3 1/2 stars out of four
  • Address: 130 W. Riverside Drive, Jeffersonville, Ind. Telephone: (812) 913-1252 Reservations: Accepted.
  • Web:OliveLeafBistro.com Cuisine: Mediterranean. Alcohol: Full bar. Vegetarian: Yes.
2 CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

There are many fine things one can say about New Jersey. First, it's next to New York. Second ... well, never mind. Who's counting? One of the best things it had going for it packed up his bags and moved south. That must have been a blow to New Jersey, but it was a stroke of good fortune for us.

Chef Jimmy Shraby loved souffls so much and was so expert at making them that he named his restaurant in Summit, N.J., Souffl. But Souffl was about much more than souffls, as is his restaurant, Olive Leaf Bistro, located on the riverfront in Jeffersonville.

I grew up in Jeffersonville and graduated from Indiana University. I have nothing against the city or its food. But, in all candor, Jeffersonville hasn't been known as a stage for impressive food performances. Until now. Shraby and Olive Leaf Bistro are celebs in the making. If Olive Leaf were located on one of Louisville's main food corridors, such as Frankfort Avenue, Market Street or Bardstown Road, Shraby would be fawned over and a reservation at his restaurant would be one of the hottest tickets in town. Until, and if ever, he makes the move to Louisville, think of Olive Leaf Bistro as a little gem with a city view.

MORE REVIEWS: Holy Grale raises the bar with impressive menu

MORE DINING: Meet Louisville's dining elite

The restaurant's Mediterranean menu is classic, not trendy. Its interior is relaxed, not flashy. Both rather cannily catch the diner off-guard.

There was nothing on the list of hors d'oeuvres that was easily ignored, especially moules a la Provencale ($9) and oysters Rockefeller ($10). However, the French onion soup ($8) and spare rib cigars ($6) led astray my friend Janet and me.

Buy Photo

The chicken Sorrentino from Olive Leaf Bistro in Jeffersonville. There's plenty of Big Four Bridge views from the dining room and deck of the Italian-Mediterranean restaurant on Riverside Drive.(Photo: By Matt Stone/The C-J)

The soup was steeped with rich flavor and topped with thick, gloriously gooey cheese that defied being spooned into any semblance of lady-like pieces.

Phyllo dough-wrapped anything promises to be tasty, although if the phyllo dough isn't perfectly baked or fried, the promise can fall flat. Shraby doesn't come across as the kind of chef who breaks promises, and he certainly didn't fall flat with his ground spare ribs wrapped in phyllo dough. I wouldn't have objected if he had paired the cigars with a sauce that had more character than the tahini sauce.

The chicken Sorrentino ($18) seduces with so much flavor that it's the epitome of guilty pleasure on a plate. After a bite or two, I thought the dish stopped just short of spectacular. I was wrong, as I discovered after perhaps the fourth bite. It didn't stop short of anything. Shraby layers eggplant, prosciutto, chicken, marinara, mozzarella and pasta so that no one ingredient gets the upper hand, but each boosts the flavor of the next.

Veal medallions au poivre vert ($20) could have been on par with the chicken Sorrentino if the veal had been slightly more tender. The delicately piquant green peppercorn sauce made up for the texture, although it obviously was not intended to overpower the meat. Shraby never diminishes one ingredient or flavor by the overuse of another. Risotto can be hit or miss, sometimes gummy and bland. Olive Leaf's wild mushroom risotto that was paired with the veal was a wild hit at our table.

Buy Photo

Veal medallions au Poivre vert with mushroom risotto from Olive Leaf Bistro in Jeffersonville.(Photo: By Matt Stone/The C-J)

The dessert menu yields sweets such as tiramisu, chocolate mousse, baklava, cannoli and coconut creme brulee, all of which are priced at $6, and all of which I hope to order another time. But, how could anyone go to a restaurant whose chef is a souffl master and not order a souffl ($9)? We couldn't.

The chocolate, Grand Marnier and raspberry souffls were pillowy clouds of decadence. I know that perfect souffls depend on how you beat the egg whites and how long you bake them, but I've always thought it helps if the gods are on your side. They must have been lined up in formation, and a couple of angels were surely sitting on Shraby's shoulders when he made the magnificent looking and tasting souffls.

The Grand Marnier Souffl is offered every evening. There's also a nightly special souffl. It might be pumpkin or caramel or whatever the chef dreams up. Thank goodness he doesn't keep his dreams to himself.

Shraby's menu, from beginning to end, is assertive but not blatant. He's a fresh, new face on the local dining scene, and his restaurant his first-rate. We're very fortunate he came our way.

You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com. Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.
